foreignObject.div: Other 5-HT receptors (GPCRs, modulate neuronal excitability and synaptic transmission)
5-HT3 receptor (ligand-gated ion channel, mediates fast excitatory neurotransmission)
Ghrelin (opposite to leptin, stimulates appetite, promotes fat storage)
Leptin (regulates appetite and energy expenditure, signals satiety)
Prolactin (stimulates milk production, affects reproductive function)
CB2 receptors (modulate immune system responses, mainly in peripheral tissues)
CB1 receptors (modulate neurotransmitter release, predominantly in the central nervous system)
Kappa (κ) opioid receptors (mediate analgesic and dysphoric effects)
Delta (δ) opioid receptors (mediate analgesic effects)
Mu (μ) opioid receptors (mediate analgesic and euphoric effects)
Beta-adrenergic receptors (β1, β2, β3) (mediate heart rate increase, relaxation of smooth muscles, and lipolysis)
Alpha-adrenergic receptors (α1, α2) (mediate vasoconstriction and neurotransmitter release inhibition)
5-HT1-7 receptors
D2-like receptors (D2, D3, D4) (mediate inhibitory effects, decrease cAMP levels)
D1-like receptors (D1, D5) (mediate excitatory effects, increase cAMP levels)
Muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (modulate neuronal excitability and synaptic transmission)
Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (mediate fast excitatory neurotransmission)
GABAB receptors (mediate slow inhibitory neurotransmission, modulate neurotransmitter release)
GABAA receptors (mediate fast inhibitory neurotransmission, regulate neuronal excitability)
Metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) (modulate neuronal excitability and synaptic transmission)
Kainate receptors (involved in modulating synaptic transmission)
AMPA receptors (involved in fast excitatory neurotransmission)
NMDA receptors (involved in synaptic plasticity, learning, and memory)
Leptin and ghrelin interact with neurotransmitter systems, such as dopamine and serotonin, to regulate appetite, reward, and mood.
Growth hormone and prolactin modulate the activity of various neurotransmitters, including dopamine, serotonin, and GABA.
Thyroid hormones can affect the levels and activity of neurotransmitters, such as serotonin and dopamine, influencing mood and cognitive function.
Oxytocin and vasopressin interact with dopamine, serotonin, and glutamate to modulate social behavior and cognition.
Stress hormones (cortisol, adrenaline, noradrenaline) are released in response to increased activity of stress-related neurotransmitters (norepinephrine and epinephrine).
Growth hormone (stimulates growth, cell reproduction, and cell regeneration)
Thyroid hormones (T3, T4) (regulate metabolism, growth, and development)
Glucagon (opposite to insulin, increases blood sugar levels by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis)
Insulin (regulates blood sugar levels, promotes glucose uptake and utilization)
Vasopressin (regulates water balance, blood pressure, and social behavior)
Oxytocin (involved in social bonding, sexual reproduction, and childbirth)
Melatonin (regulates sleep-wake cycle)
Noradrenaline (stress hormone, increases alertness, focus, and blood flow)
Adrenaline (stress hormone, increases heart rate, blood pressure, and metabolic rate)
Cortisol (stress hormone, increases blood sugar and suppresses immune system)
Endocannabinoids (involved in mood, appetite, pain, and other physiological processes)
Endogenous opioids (involved in pain modulation, reward, and addiction)
Norepinephrine & Epinephrine (involved in stress response, attention, and alertness)
Serotonin (involved in mood, appetite, sleep, and other physiological processes)
Dopamine (involved in reward, motivation, motor control, and cognition)
Acetylcholine (modulates attention, learning, memory, and motor function)
GABA (inhibitory neurotransmitter)
Glutamate (excitatory neurotransmitter)
3. Relationships between neurotransmitters and hormones
2. Hormones
1. Neurotransmitters
Brain Chemistry
